docs.lead_paragraph: School kids, truckers, marijuana smokers and fans of old-fashioned light bulbs are among the millions of people who had something extra riding on the big spending bill passed by Congress to keep the government running.

headline.main: The $1.1T Bill: School Lunches, Light Bulbs, Pot
headline.print_headline: The $1.1T Bill: School Lunches, Light Bulbs, Pot

docs.lead_paragraph: Flourishing billionaires, racial divides. Finally, people seem fed up.
docs.abstract: Mark Bittman Op-Ed column contends spontaneous protests around country about issues ranging from the minimum wage to deaths of black men at hands of police seem to indicate that many in the country are fed up; maintains that all issues are connected, and that solutions to those issues are to keep pressure on politicians and those in power by continually protesting.
docs.snippet: Flourishing billionaires, racial divides. Finally, people seem fed up.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bulletproof drink, which is a mug of coffee blended with butter, claims its unique 450-calorie cup of joe promotes weight loss and provides mental clarity.

headline.main: The Cult of the Bulletproof Coffee Diet
headline.print_headline: One Lump of Butter or Two?

docs.abstract: Butter-infused Bulletproof coffee is latest trend in Silicon Valley, Calif; fans claim the drink promotes weight loss and provides mental clarity.
docs.snippet: The Bulletproof drink, which is a mug of coffee blended with butter, claims its unique 450-calorie cup of joe promotes weight loss and provides mental clarity.

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew Solomon reviews a new book by Jay Griffiths, who says contemporary society denies children the freedoms of space, time and the natural world.

headline.main: ‘A Country Called Childhood,’ by Jay Griffiths

docs.abstract: Andrew Solomon reviews book A Country Called Childhood: Children and the Exuberant World by Jay Griffiths.
docs.snippet: Andrew Solomon reviews a new book by Jay Griffiths, who says contemporary society denies children the freedoms of space, time and the natural world.

docs.lead_paragraph: When man’s best friend gets too fat, that pet becomes a potential fitness aid for its owner.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal spending bill includes funding for Middle East military operations, raises political donation limits and provides funds to fight Ebola.

headline.main: From Contribution Limits to the Sage Grouse: What Is in the Spending Bill?

docs.lead_paragraph: A Kansas obesity specialist who co-authored the "Atkins Diabetes Revolution" has been sentenced to three years and five months in federal prison for tax evasion, the U.S. attorney's office announced Friday.

headline.main: Atkins Diet Co-Author Sentenced to 41 Months
headline.print_headline: Atkins Diet Co-Author Sentenced to 41 Months

docs.snippet: A Kansas obesity specialist who co-authored the "Atkins Diabetes Revolution" has been sentenced to three years and five months in federal prison for tax evasion, the U.S. attorney's office announced Friday.

docs.lead_paragraph: A French countess, who sold off her jewels, artwork and real estate to build an unusual village-based anti-poverty program, plans to release details of the initiative next year as an open source tool-kit for other NGOs.

headline.main: End Poverty? Sometimes It Really May Take a Village
headline.print_headline: End Poverty? Sometimes It Really May Take a Village

docs.snippet: A French countess, who sold off her jewels, artwork and real estate to build an unusual village-based anti-poverty program, plans to release details of the initiative next year as an open source tool-kit for other NGOs.
